content:
I am a researcher at the Niels Bohr Institute at the University of Copenhagen, developing photonic technologies to accelerate quantum and classical computing.
Previously, I was a Postdoctoral Fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology with Quantum Photonics Lab and a PhD student at the University of Bristol Centre for Quantum Photonics.
​I have been awarded a Marie-Skłodowska Curie Global Fellowship, attended the 66th Landau Nobel Laureates Meeting and was a UK finalist in FameLab.
summary:
I am a researcher at the Niels Bohr Institute at the University of Copenhagen, developing photonic technologies to accelerate quantum and classical computing.

title: Jacques Carolan

title: How to verify that quantum chips are computing correctly

content:
I develop large-scale photonic integrated circuits that can be reprogrammed to implement a host of optical transformations, all on a single device. Such universal programable photonics may enable breakthroughs in quantum computing, artificial intelligence, imaging and signals processing.
Papers  J. Carolan, C. Harrold, C. Sparrow, E. Martı́n-López, N. J. Russell, J. W. Silverstone, P. J. Shadbolt, N. Matsuda, M. Oguma, M. Itoh, G. D. Marshall, M. G. Thompson, J. C. F. Matthews, T. Hashimoto, J. L. O’Brien, A. Laing  (2015). Universal linear optics. Science 349, 711 (2015).  PDF  Cite   arXiv  Web    U. Chakraborty, J. Carolan, G. Clark, D. Bunandar, J. Notaros, M. R. Watts, D. R. Englund  (2020). Cryogenic operation of silicon photonic modulators based on DC Kerr effect. arXiv preprint arXiv:2007.03395 (2020).  PDF  Cite   arXiv   Reviews  N. C. Harris, J. Carolan, D. Bunandar, M. Prabhu, M. Hochberg, T. Baehr-Jones, M. L. Fanto, A. M. Smith, C. C. Tison, P. M. Alsing, D. Englund  (2018). Linear programmable nanophotonic processors. Optica 5, 1623 (2018).  PDF  Cite  Web    J. Kim, S. Aghaeimeibodi, J. Carolan, D. Englund, E. Waks  (2020). Hybrid integration methods for on-chip quantum photonics. Optica 7, 291 (2020).  PDF  Cite   arXiv  Web
summary: I develop large-scale photonic integrated circuits that can be reprogrammed to implement a host of optical transformations, all on a single device. Such universal programable photonics may enable breakthroughs in quantum computing, artificial intelligence, imaging and signals processing.
title: Programmable Photonics

title: ​One Small Optical Chip, One Giant Leap for Quantum Computing

content:
I’m fascinated by the intersection of machine learning and quantum mechanics; both in terms of how we can use quantum processors to accelerate machine learning and how we can leverage techniques from machine learning to help control and verify large-scale quantum systems.
Papers  J. Carolan, M. Mohseni, J. P. Olson, M. Prabhu, C. Chen, D. Bunandar, M. Y. Niu, N. C. Harris, F. N. C. Wong, M. Hochberg, S. Lloyd, D. Englund  (2020). Variational quantum unsampling on a quantum photonic processor. Nature Physics 16, 322 (2020).  PDF  Cite   arXiv  Web    G. R. Steinbrecher, J. P Olson, D. Englund, J. Carolan  (2019). Quantum optical neural networks. npj Quantum Information 5, 60 (2019).  PDF  Cite   arXiv  Web    M. Prabhu, C. Roques-Carmes, Y. Shen, N. Harris, L. Jing, J. Carolan, R. Hamerly, T. Baehr-Jones, M. Hochberg, V. Čeperić, J. D. Joannopoulos, D. R. Englund, M. Soljačić  (2020). Accelerating recurrent Ising machines in photonic integrated circuits. Optica 7, 551 (2020).  PDF  Cite   arXiv  Web
summary: I’m fascinated by the intersection of machine learning and quantum mechanics; both in terms of how we can use quantum processors to accelerate machine learning and how we can leverage techniques from machine learning to help control and verify large-scale quantum systems.
title: Quantum for AI & AI for Quantum

content:
Scalable methods to generate, manipulate and detect quantum states of light on chip may enable a new paradigm for computing. I build such quantum technologies in a variety of material platforms, alongside developing a new suite of algorithms for machine learning, chemistry and secure communication.
Papers  J. Carolan, U. Chakraborty, N. C. Harris, M. Pant, T. Baehr-Jones, M. Hochberg, D. Englund  (2019). Scalable feedback control of single photon sources for photonic quantum technologies. Optica 6, 335 (2019).  PDF  Cite   arXiv  Web    C. Sparrow, E. Martı́n-López, N. Maraviglia, A. Neville, C. Harrold, J. Carolan, Y. N Joglekar, T. Hashimoto, N. Matsuda, J. L. O’Brien, D. Tew, A. Laing  (2018). Simulating the vibrational quantum dynamics of molecules using photonics. Nature 557, 660 (2018).  PDF  Cite  Web    J. Carolan, J. D. A. Meinecke, P. J. Shadbolt, N. J. Russell, N. Ismail, K. Wörhoff, T. Rudolph, M. G Thompson, J. L. O'Brien, J. C. F. Matthews, A. Laing  (2014). On the experimental verification of quantum complexity in linear optics. Nature Photonics 8, 621 (2014).  PDF  Cite   arXiv  Web
summary: Scalable methods to generate, manipulate and detect quantum states of light on chip may enable a new paradigm for computing. I build such quantum technologies in a variety of material platforms, alongside developing a new suite of algorithms for machine learning, chemistry and secure communication.
title: Quantum Photonics

content: Having trained at Improv Boston, I’ve performed in a number of teams, including Phoenix Killbot at IB’s Indie Exposure, Hot Buttered Toads and Improvised History. In addition, I’ve performed standup comedy across the south coast of the UK including Bright Club at the Bloomsbury Theatre.
summary: I'm an improv comedian and standup comic, and have performed across New England and Old England.
title: Comedy

summary: Confessions of a Clumsy Scientist brings together totally true, anonymous stories of monumental mess-ups by real life scientists.
title: Confessions of a Clumsy Scientist

title: FameLab
